p.s: One can say Helen is a looser of the common american dreamAmerican Dream and a child with many social problems.
The eight year old Helen looks like she is five (l. 2).
It seems as if she is stuck on a former phase of life.
One of the most important aspects to say about Helen is that she used to be broken inside but she is still a happy child Helen smiled (l. 3).
Helen was raised up in such bad living conditions, where she needed to reuse dental floss (l. 15) or wherwhere she was given one square of toilet paper a day (l. 15).
Normally people that experiencesexperience this kind of treatment want to give up but Helen with her positive, innocent way of thinking still makes the best out of her life.
With this information the author tries to point out her strong character.
She sets focuses on her past to underline this.
Helen is a confused child.
She is overburden with a background story therefore she talks nonstop (l. 5).
Because of her at least seventeen different foster homes Helen had never a clear point to return or to talk with, so it comes up to mind that taking is her way to deal with it.
She never had one person to trust that showed her how to live so Helen finds her own way (l. 12-13).
The fact that HelensHelen speaks to herself in third person (l. 17) and the fact that nobody corrects her (l. 17) is especially chosen from the author to underline this characteristic traits.
There was never a safety place for her.
It is almost like there is no sonssense in her life (l. 23).
Despite all of this negative social background information Helen has no negative feelings.
And that is an amazing character trait which is pointed out.
HelensHelen's huge telephone collection is a symbol for her relationships to her former life (l. 24).
The reader is astonished about the number of phones Helen keeps.
But on the other hand the reader feels how important these phones are to her because Leo needs to repair them: I promised her I'll try and sort out on day (ll. 28-29).

Of course one can say Helen never called so her foster families mean nothing to her but you can see a sort of relationship here that is underlined because Helen speaks of her own houses (l. 30) not of something bad.

Another important information is that Helen says she does have three more closer friends (ll. 32-33) so it is clearly said by the author that she still havehas a sort of relationship to her former homes and a positive way of thinking.
To put it all in a nutshell one can say that Jennifer Clement really created an interesting new character with Helen.
The true foster child lives a dot-to-dot life with too many changes and families for her young age.
But Helen herself isn't clear about it so her innocent way of thinking only allowallows positive aspects of her former life.
But in her way of speaking one can still see that in her childhood was not everything right.
Even thothough Helen has had such bad living conditions she will not give up what shows her strong character traits.
